title: Before 1 January 2019, will either house of Congress pass a bill that would limit the president's authority to impose tariffs?
preds: Well it's the government shutdown. So no.
Next year the house will.  Too late now.
Talk about ships that have sailed.
Both houses are still controlled by Republicans and they are unwilling to cross Trump.
This will not happen at this point because the Congressional agenda is set through the holiday. Time is running out.
Extremely unlikely given the GOP control of both chambers until Jan 2019 and the time remaining in the year.
Not in 2018.  The House likely will in 2019, but it won't get past the Senate, and even if it does, it obviously gets vetoed by Trump.  Not even worth paying attention to.  More Washington theater.
current congress is paralyzed and has other priorities
Elections are over, GOP doesn't care about tariffs. If they did, they would have already done something.

Trump has threatened to impose tariffs on foreign cars and car parts in the name of national security. A Commerce Department report that could lead to tariffs is due by February and several attempts by lawmakers this year to limit Trump’s unilateral tariff powers have failed.
No chance. Not this Congress under this President.

LOL.  Seriously, the executive branch is at peak power in peacetime ever, besides the gre. Depression.  You think this congress would or could limit the power of its very own party sitting president?  Phhhht! Stupid question.

There is not enough spine in the current Congress to build an amoeba, so this is right out.  If the Ds take both chambers in the next Congress they may pass such a bill to be vetoed by The Leader Of The Free World as soon as he can wrap his tiny fingers around a pen, but the next Congress is not seated until after this deadline.
Wouldn’t that be a bit out of character for this group of over indulged tribalists

Bet#7 was 1 now 0. 434 (2 today) from 246. @0.02
Clearing old bets list.

Tariffs convey a message to local population that their elected representatives are doing something to battle cheap imports which threaten their pocketbooks. Tarrifs are a language in which Trump is not only talking to Chinese, Europeans, Indians etc, through through tariffs Trump is also telling the heartland that someone is looking out for them, even though in the end it will not make economic sense.

The only people who care about the tariffs are the policy wonks. So, given economy is going well and no one is really feeling the tariffs yet there's no incentive to make legislation. Even if there was, these things take time, which we're running low on.
Can't be done, even if the tariff-setting becomes horribly wreckless.  It's Congress' job to step in.
Seems really unlikely unless there is an economic downturn, which also seems unlikely in the short run.

GOP will not do this. Leaders in Congress have mounted no significant challenge to T's use of tariffs even against Canada. Things will change if Dems win in November but new Congress will convene until January, 2019, so no action this year.
they will get tangled with other things!!!
I'm guessing it wouldn't be the first order of business for a newly Democratic chamber.

The tariffs are internally popular at the moment.  It will take a long time for any repercussions to filter through, and even then there will be plausible deniability (for those that wish to use it) regarding the connection to the tariffs.
it would be originally a Republian thing to do, but...

The US economy is the mother of capitalism. Its economy depends highly on budget realization via tax collection. Due to the sensitive nature of this issue, it is unlikely such powers would be taken from the President!

He’s actually using them to good effect (as leverage in negotiations). Love him or hate him, Trump is juggling a great deal semi-effectively (far more than predecessor). Let’s just hope the balls don’t start dropping...
Very unlikely given the current climate. Current congress will hold fast to everything thing they are able to.

Both parties are loathe to take any action against Trump legislatively. With midterm elections in November that leaves less than two months before 1/1/19 for a body of Congress to come together enough to pass a bill opposing a Trump policy. Only a huge cataclysmic event will lead  to such a bill passing by then.
This issue will be too controversial for an election year and will run counter to the results that the President is achieving.

https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-congress-trade/u-s-senate-quietly-votes-to-cut-tariffs-on-hundreds-of-chinese-goods-idUSKBN1KG35R
This doesn't "limit the president's authority"; it just exercises Congress' authority  The same thing happens when Congress passes a bill that overrides an executive order:  The president's authority to issue executive orders is not limited, but the legislative power is asserted.
It is that lame duck congress that worries me on an otherwise solid no.
No as the trade war goes on Trump has his way.
Time up date this is a hard judgment to make.

https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trade-senate/u-s-senators-blast-trump-on-trade-vow-to-press-for-change-in-policy-idUSKBN1K22RK
There are rumblings of mutiny among Rs in both chambers, but it would be a mistake to discount the spinelessness in that population.  When it comes to a vote, they will most likely revert to their usual gelatinous state.  Will somebody please remind me why I am still registered Republican?
Back down due to non-binding bill won't actually limit the authority. Thanks to Emil's comment https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/757197
Passed in Senate 88-11, but not binding?
Agh, will resolve with parsing by the legal eagles of GJO.
As long as the markets don't overreact, the Republicans in power are going to be happy to ride that wave and not buck the President.
Congress doesn’t have the will to pass anything of consequence
Pulling out of the WTO now? Anything could happen.

The president is upsetting the established norms in international trade and it is hurting business - a lot of business. It will get worse and will have to be stopped by congress at the behest of their corporate sponsors and friends. Money for business and money for congress is too closely interdependent to allow this disruption to continue unchecked.

Some members will need to appear to fight the president on this and there is always that chance that a bill will slip through one house or the other. So far Dems like Macaskill in Mo. are combining with Detroit to decry the tariffs. In Arkansas however - a multi Billion dollar set of Steel Mill expansions is under way as is activity up and down the Mississippi. Detroit doesn't want to buy american steel but they want You to buy American....so the issue in the spin zone till the hard numbers start to develop. I'm at 15% because i haven't seen a trend establish on the SCOTUS BATTLE and Democratic turnout. If the Dems get excited over SCOTUS nominee anything could happen.

For some reason I believe the upcoming elections will come out worse than I personally hope. I think Trump will not lose as many seeats as I hope and as would be good for the world. So I don't think there is enough power in either of the houses and it's more likely there won't be any bill to impose the tariffs.
Kaum einer möchte so am abgrund taumeln .....Denn nach fest kommt ab...
There will be attempts because the tariffs will hurt the US economy
It is a republican congress and senate.
Congress will not get involved before the mid-term elections
Almost impossible to see enough political will to achieve this with mid terms looming and limited appetite from the republican side to cause offence to POTUS.

It's possible that by later this year, Trumps' foolish tariffs will be costing company's money  and people their jobs. When they finally realize that these measures are hitting them in the wallet, that will turn to their representative or congressman and demand that something be done. Now a choice has to be made. Quiver in fear of the president and do nothing, or,  realize that their constituents could vote them out of office for not addressing their concerns. However, they could pass a bill trying to limit the president's power, thus satisfying the voters and increasing their chances of getting re-elected. They would know full well, of course, that the Senate would not take up the bill, thus insuring that it would never become law, giving them what they really wanted all along. As usual, these legislative members would be doing that which they always do: have their cake and eat too while standing before the national news cameras and "sincerely?" telling the public they are working diligently and honestly on their behalf. Our politics have become such a circus and a sham.
No indication of a sufficient willingness to do so.

https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trade-senate/senate-will-not-poke-the-bear-trump-by-passing-tariff-measure-lawmaker-idUSKBN1J82WV?il=0
Not happening.  Even if Inhofe lets it go, Yertle the Distinguished Majority Leader will stop it from getting to the floor.
Congress is coming to the harsh reality of that policy change is required.
Maybe some in Congress will try to 'monetize' the issue during Donnie's second term.
Even with it introduced, no way it will pass, especially with all the GOP congresspeople up for re-election this year cuddling up to Trump.

Dissension is growing even among the GOP, about the Tariffs. Democrats obviously disapprove. (So does most of the GOP privately, but now publicly they seem to be getting disgruntled.)
Our allies EU and Canada are getting really irritated, and rightly so. THe next few days will reveal clues as the G-7 meet, and doubtless express their umbrage to Trump. What Trump needs is some kind of political cover, because of his ego. 
Maybe the allies will be able to think of something to "give" him, so he won't look, well golly, like he is being economically rational.
Or perhaps the midterm elections will put pressure on him, as prices begin to spike in consumer goods.
Wishful thinking actually, but I doubt it will happen.
Congress is spineless. But if Dems win a chamber, and get enough pressure, they might try.

This forecast depends on who will control the House or Senate until the end of the year.
At this moment, both chambers are Republicans. After November election, both will remain in Republicans' control during the lameduck session. The new Congress will be sworn in in January 2019, regardless of who win the November election. 
What Republicans would do? Nothing. There is no  benefit for them to join the Democrats and alienate Trump supporters. Plus, it seems Trump uses trade war and tariffs as a negotiating tool and anchor his position. Remember also that other administrations including Bush have imposed tariffs before. Only because Trump is more vocal about it and the scorched earth tactics from his opponents that we talk about limiting administration power. Europeans and Chinese imposed tariffs all the time. For example, they imposed 35 to 42% on steel import into China some time before 2016.

No chance given Republicans control Congress until then at least, and will not cross a popular president of their own party. Also, President Trump is likely to resolve some disputes via negotiation to mitigate the tariff threats.

20% yes, with the current Congress that will remain until January 2019, it is not likely that they will limit the presidentâ€™s authority to impose tariffs, as President Trump uses them frequently, and it is not likely the republican controlled congress will defy this. This is also strictly included in the constitution under the President, and I do not believe it will ever be changed.
Depends on how rumbly Trump gets and how bad it starts hitting Republican districts.

A bill limiting the president authority on trade may come on some Point, and its timeline might be accelerated by DT imposing tariffs based on the Claim of national security issues. However even if the tariffs are enacted, which is far from sure, it might still be repealed in court. Therefore i expect the Congress to only take Action if the tariffs are imposed and if the court sides with the president. And then still there is a fair Chance that the bill is either brought to a vote after 01.01.2019 or simply does not pass one of the houses.

Passing bills takes time and energy that is not there right now. Also, Republican control of Congress would prevent any action that could damage the President's efficacy/policies as it would reflect badly on the party.
I don't think the republican congress will do anything to stop Trump

The free-trade lobby in Congress may be numerous, but it's not going to be aggressive. Most Republicans wouldn't dare cross Trump on this, especially before primaries and mid-term elections. Many Democrats, especially from the Mid-West, also lean toward protectionism.

No way. Politicians may be pretty dumb, but when it comes to, as Australia's greatest Prime Minister Paul Keating says a horse named 'Self-Interest': back it. Politicians can be pretty short-term thinking but they know not to curtail their own powers. Just look at Obama promising to close Gitmo and roll back the spying and killing. Didn't happen.
quite doubtful but one can hope

With mid terms approaching, Congressional Republicans are going to want to do something to show their constituents that they aren't completely tied to Trump's sinking ship. However, I am attenuating that possibility with the fact that the Congressional Republicans don't seem to have the organizational skills necessary to order pizzas for lunch.
A Republican controlled Congress is unlikely to make this precedent, despite some Republican dissenters to Trump's tariffs.

Not enough time to debate such a controversial bill due to administration chaos, Congressional divisions, Republican party infighting and differences, preoccupation with mid-term elections, summer break and general apathy and confusion as to what the priorities should be. Too many splinter groups among republicans, all with their own partisan / personal agendas which each considers a priority, with no regard and total indifference to real and rational government for the entire country.
Because they've refused to limit his authority to this point.  They frog is now uncomfortably boiling.
The Democrats don't have the power and the Republicans are emasculated, spineless puppets, so zero percent chance.
Republicans have lost their spines and moral compasses with President Trump and won't do a thing.  Tariffs are popular in election years.

The power to conduct international trade lies with Congress, so implementing such a rule would not undermine the president's constitutional authority. That being said, since the 1930's there has been a trend towards the President assuming more of this international trade power by Congressional delegation. For Congress to pass legislation limiting this would not be without precedent but it would be a significant action against an established trend. Because Congress is currently dominated by the Republican party mostly aligning with the president and will continue to be so until January of 2019, I believe it is unlikely they would seek to limit the president's actions in what could come across as a sort of vote of no faith in response to one tariff.
the counter tariff will apply for the most part to jobs and products in Trumps base states
Tariffs are counter productive. Other countries such as China will retaliate and US exports will decline
someone needs to rein him in.

Republicans are supine before this president to the point of treason against the people who elected him. Democrats lack the numbers to beat a filibuster if they tried to impose such a bill. This may change after midterms with the increase of Democrats ascendant, but not a guarantee until after 2020 election when Blue Wave fully breaks.
it is unlikely that any such bill would make it past committee. and then would be very unlikely garner 50% votes.
Neither house will pass significant legislation before the mid-terms.

Usually congress doesn't do this sort of this, but President Trump is an unusual president. All projections show that the Democrats have never gone below a 50% chance of winning a majority in the midterm elections (http://www.thecrosstab.com/2018-midterms-forecast/). If/When Democrats win a majority this fall, this sort of thing becomes easier to do. Congress tends to over-'correct' after a time in which one party controls both the executive and legislature.
opposition will grow, perhaps even more so if Rs lose seats in the midterms

If Trump stops at steel and aluminum, then they won't feel they need to; Congress needs a huge reason to act and even if the Dems win control of the House and Senate in November, this probably won't be a top priority.  Politically, some people like the tariffs.
Seriously unlikely given the history of Congress ceding powers to the President. Can’t think of a time In the current era when they put up a strong effort to get them back.

It is unlikely that Congress will impose any such restriction even in a lame duck session. This would likely only occur if the President unilaterally decided to engage in trade warfare that would have lasting and negative implications.
The reaction by the stock market to uncertainty arising from irrational behavior
No, because Trump is the new bully in DC,
The Republican-controlled Congress has shown little willingness to go against President Trump's choices, and it's unlikely that anything will be different for this issue.

Republican Congress & Senate will support Mr.
Trump, at least for this year.

Can Congress pass anything more before and immediately following midterm elections this year?  Not likely and this would not be at the top of any short list that could make it with the necessary votes.  Sorry Chamber of Commerce you will not pull this off.

Not gonna happen.  There are just now too many Ds who prefer protectionism because their labour union bosses tell them to, and too many Rs who through terror of Mr. Tangerine Man have abandoned all pretense of principle.  Between them they will stop this from happening.  Political courage, never abundant in any polity, has pretty much gone on indefinite leave from both parties in the US.
Republicans have already protested and now they're done. Unless the economy tips into a recession I doubt they will do anything more.
Not a chance in my opinion.

https://www.forbes.com/sites/sarahsu/2016/11/14/how-far-can-trump-go-on-chinese-trade-policy/#777be9cd1dd1
Tariffs can only be imposed unilaterally by President when there is material injury to the domestic industry for a  max of 15% and for 150 days to combat balance of payments deficits.
No way, anytime soon, Iâ€™d believe.....

It's not very likely at the moment. However, if the WH starts slapping countries with tariffs, or opting not to exclude friends, allies, and trade partners, it's possible one of the chambers takes action (more likely the Senate, as the GOP knows the House can let it die via the Hastert rule). But unless the tariffs begin to affect polling numbers disproportionately, thus forcing members to demand action before the November elections, its more likely a new Congress would take action next year.
